segments.text: What is the battery in there?
It's fine.
It's in a machine.
Dr. Peter Abrahams, and that's right there.
Congratulations on your new book.
Well, thank you very much.
Tell me, I mean, for my purposes, this is perfect.
I'm a big baseball fan.
We're probably not going to have baseball this year.
It looks that way.
You afford me the opportunity to write an interesting piece for the first week of April.
About baseball.
About baseball, but also...
Are there any number of possibilities with this?
Certainly.
Tell me a little bit about the concept of this book.
I mean, it's certainly not just a baseball book.
It's about madness and obsession.
You know, Susan was asking me what the genesis of it was, how I began.
You know, when I started to think about this, it was at Fenway Park.
Do you mind if I shoot a couple?
No, that's all right.
Susan, didn't she send you anything?
Yeah, but I have some customers that say color, so... Oh, okay.
All right.
We offer that.
Okay.
All right.
Well, Susan said, I mean, I was at Fenway Park a few years ago with my brother, and I think we had two of my boys.
My two sons were there, too, I think.
This was the year when the Red Sox were very competitive, I think, at least at that part of the season.
And the Blue Jays were in town.
And my brother is a big Blue Jays fan.
He doesn't live here.
He lives in Los Angeles.
And he's a big Blue Jays fan.
And so he was cheering for the Blue Jays at Fenway Park.
And these two Red Sox, young male fans, began jeering him.
And they went.
It became much more than just like... Against my brother, who was... It became much more than... Okay, they had plenty to drink.
And it became much more... You know when suddenly you look at someone and you see it all in a new light and it can be quite scary?
I looked at their faces and I thought, my God, if we weren't at the ballpark, this would be... These guys are dangerous, almost.
And the image of them has stayed with me.
you know, these two guys.
I don't think my brother saw it this way particularly, but I did, and it began to stay with me.

I began to get the idea of some fan who, I mean, I was thinking about how people, me too, I mean, have, you know, follow sports, has a lot of genuine emotion invested in what obviously turns out to be the business of baseball.
You know, it's like,
I have no emotion invested in how General Motors is doing.
If the car dealer has a good week, I couldn't care less.
Whereas if the Red Sox are, you know, I do have genuine emotion invested in something where maybe you shouldn't.
And then when I look at people like this, I mean, these two fans who, you know, were in a mental state about her.
Did you see instantly the germ of a novel?
No, oh no, I didn't... No, no.
I don't... It doesn't work that way for me.
I get maybe three or four ideas a year that I think could be a novel, but I don't... When the idea comes, I just... I don't do anything with it.
I wait to see if it keeps coming back and kind of grows on its own for a while before I actually engage with it.
To make... I mean, this is just my MO, that...
and maybe it's even superstition in some ways, that if it's strong enough to keep knocking at my door, then there's something there.
If I have to, in the early stages, go get it, you know, and cudgel my brain, then it isn't going to be big enough, and I just wait for another one.
Now, this is, I think, your eighth movie, is that right?
Yes.
Fifteen years, which is pretty productive.
That's what my grandmother says, but I really think I'm slow.
I really do."
And she said, oh, Peter, you're doing it.
But I think that's great.
You just had a book last year that was shortlisted for the Edgar Award, I think.
Yeah, Lights Out.
We'll find out in April.
And here you are, 95.
It was actually ready in 94.
So, I mean, how long did it take to your write one?
It's longer and longer.
The actual writing of this, I'm not going back to when I had
the idea and when it kind of grew.
But the actual writing, I think, took about eight months.
Now, of course, the house was in its worst.
We moved in during that period.
How long have you been here?
How long has the house been under construction?
Well, we... This is not on my page, but... No, we moved in last... Okay, we had problems.
We moved in last December, and we had problems with our building.
Not the builder who was doing the garage.
He's been fabulous, and he's even ahead of schedule.
But the builder was doing the house.
I don't know what happened.
I think he has to do something with his wife.
And he lost a kind of interest and didn't come like for months at a time when we had to be in here.
Or his workers would show up for a day or two and then they'd be gone.
It was one of these Cape building stories you hear about.
We had thought we had done everything possible to avoid.
Were you living in the cave prior to this?
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
We've lived here since 1982.
Oh.
Yeah.
In Woods Hole.
We were in Woods Hole before.
Really?
Yeah.
We were just going to interview Robert Ballard in a couple weeks.
He has a book coming out.
Uh-huh.
I've never even met him.
I know he is.
The book looks good.
Yeah.
If you don't mind jumping around a little bit here.
No.
You're a boss.
You might just give me a little bit of a biographical background.
Well, I was born in Boston.
Brookline, to be precise.
And my father and my mother met at the Naval Hospital during the war.
She was from Ottawa, Canada.
Which Naval Hospital?
In Boston.
I'm not sure which one.
I can call my father.
No, no, no.
It's in Boston.
Yeah.
Boston Naval Hospital.
Well, I mean, was some VA... I'm not sure because... See, my mother's Uncle Jack from Milton.
was the commanding officer of a cruiser that was sunk in the Battle of the Coral Sea.
And he's one of these horrible stories with sharks, and he was in the water for 14 hours.
And so he was in... He made it.
Yeah, he made it, and he was recovering in the hospital.
As soon as the Naval Hospital.
There is a Naval Hospital.
Yeah, with other Naval guys.
And he shared a room with my father, who was a 20-year-old...
Had he even graduated from college?
He was at Williams.
I think he had... He was 20 years old and he was commanding a sub-chaser in the Atlantic.
He was only a lieutenant junior grade, but that's what happened in Orbe.
It was unbelievable.
At his age, I couldn't get up out of bed in the morning and get to class a long time, and he was doing that.
Anyway, he was in the hospital, too, with a very bad case of athlete's foot.
With my Uncle Jack, this war hero, and my dad with athlete's foot sharing a room.
I spent a few years in the Navy.
Oh, did you?
Yeah.
Were you in the Vietnam War?
Vietnam.
I was in Lieutenant J.G., which is... So nothing's changed, right?
Nothing's changed.
So my mom came down to visit my Uncle Jack.
And that's how they met.
And in fact, they honeymooned at the Cape Cod Hotel, which is now... Do you know where that is?
It's very close to here.
It's just around the corner on Syphilissa.
And that's where... Do you still wear it?
No.
Oh, and people tried to say it was a lovely old place.
And there are condos there now.
Yeah, it turned into a whole condo thing.
They tore it down.
You know, we used to go for drinks and watch the sunset.
A real cape-y thing.
But it's condo.
I mean, this, during all the condo-ization, it went down here a few years ago.
And of course, now they're everywhere, and people have lost their shirts.
I mean, it's one of those things.
So I was born in Boston, but...
My father, after the war, went to dental school at McGill University in Montreal.
And they moved to Ottawa.
So I grew up partly in Ottawa.
And then they got divorced and my mother moved to the Bahamas.
So I spent a lot of time there too.
I went to Williams College in Massachusetts as he did.
I graduated in 68.
And a very unfortunate thing happened during, in my freshman year, they made a big rule change and made classroom attendance no longer compulsory.
And for someone like me, that was just the worst thing that could have happened.
So I really didn't know that.
But you graduated?
But I did graduate.
I'm not sure it was the best thing that I did graduate.
What was your major?
English.
But I was a really horrible student.
Until the very end, in senior year, I started getting interested in art history and took a lot of art history courses, which I really enjoyed.
And I went to class, and of course, that just, like magic, improves your grades.
You know, just being there, you know.
Let's see, what else?
In the Bahamas, I got into scuba diving and freediving.
And I used to work as a summer job as a spear fisherman down there.
And so after I got out of college, I had no idea what I wanted to do.
I kept doing spearing fish for a living.
You made a living at this?
Well, of a kind.
I mean, you didn't need much money.
And we'd go to a hotel if my brother was down there, and if not, I'd do it.
We'd say, if you give me a place to live, like on a houseboat or just a little cabin, I'll supply all the fish you need for 50 cents a pound, some really low price.
It was just an excuse to spearfish.
I mean, there's some incredible diving down there in Poms.
And we did it free diving, which is a very good sport.
more fair from a fish's point of view.
How long were you down there?
Oh, off and on for a number of years.
Kind of get us into the... becoming a writer again.
Okay, well, my mother was a writer.
And your mother's name is... She's dead now.
In fact, can you tell her your name?
Enid was her first name.
Enid Abraham?
Enid Abrahams at one time, yeah.
How was the writer?
She wrote...
Teleplays for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.
Oh, yeah.
Yes.
Oh, yeah.
And had many produced.
Great.
She was a professional writer.
Oh, yes.
When you say she's a writer, you mean she's a professional writer.
She was a professional writer.
Oh, absolutely.
And sometimes I've taught a few courses, like at the Cape Cod Writers Conference, where people come and want to be writers, and they always say, well, you know, how much of this can you learn?
And how much do you have to be born with?
You know, they ask me that over and over.
Yeah, and I don't know the answer.
But in my own case, I'm not even sure I can parse out what I was born with and what I learned, because at a very young age, I was in a class where a lot of writing happened.
Every week there'd be a composition of some kind, and I'd bring these home and show me my mother.
And she would say to me, what would happen if you put that word over there?
Or is there another way to say this?
Or how does this link up?
Or this is a word you should never use.
Okay, she had these.
And even today, I have... What are some of the words?
Oh, any linking word, like however, nevertheless, moreover.
I never use those.
You won't find them, except in direct speech, you know, where some characters use them.
But I will never use them because the links have to be logical.
Okay, that was one of the things she taught me.
I, in fact... A rule, excellent rule, right?
Oh, I think so, too.
Oh, everything she told me is right.
In fact, I kind of codified it into five laws, Enid's laws.
What happened?
Oh, let's see.
Organization is everything.
Push everything as far as you can.
Never contri... Break that one down a little bit.
Why don't we go through the five and go back?
Okay.
You can push everything as far as you can.
In other words...
Well, this is sort of related to another one, which is that fiction, like wrestling, is about reversals.
In other words, you don't ever let a character off easily out of any situation, even though to do so makes the writing much easier.
You push every situation to the absolute limit without sacrificing credibility that you can.
And I think she's right.
I mean, you get, it's in the extreme situation where, I'm not talking about being sensational.
That's, you know what I mean, like sensational, isn't it?
It's just to get to the edge.
I mean, I think you get your more exciting work there.
Okay, how many organizations have you pushed it?
And that's the one I always tell people first, because it's so dry and unarty.
And I think that's important.
Yes, organization.
You must be a very careful outliner.
No, but I believe it.
You see, the other thing is, I don't like to get trapped in the outline.
So at the beginning, my outline starts, sort of like this house, as it was being built, everything was beautiful, planned, and so well organized.
And then as it goes along, it gets more and more big.
And that's okay, because things happen in the middle of the story where, I mean, as in the fan, I mean, I, Jewel Stern, the female sports reporter, was supposed to be quite a minor figure.
And the first time she opened her mouth in the story, I knew she wasn't going to.
But she just becomes pretty important.
Yes.
Yeah, and she just grew.
And she, if I'd done an outline, she would have been very minor.
And she just, once she opened her mouth, I wanted more and more.
We probably got her.
this new breed of woman who was very knowledgeable about sports.
I was just guessing.
No, you're absolutely right.
But they're different from the... I kind of felt that they have a little more detachment from it.
I mean, they have this other perspective that comes from being a woman.
And they never, as a little boy,
because they weren't a little boy, you know, dreamed about one day putting on Yankee pinstripes, because it's an impossible dream for them.
And I think, I mean, another thing the fans are about is like all this boyhood baseball.
Well, the little league, I mean, that was terrific.
He's talking about how the good skill happened.
He's talking about the teams in double-A or triple-A or something, but it's a little league game from Kai's.
Yeah, that's right.
Anyway, I'm sorry to interrupt you.
No, you can interrupt.
I have four kids.
Organization is everything.
Push everything.
Okay, never contrive.
Did I say that?
That's your third one.
Yeah, never contrive.
Fiction is about reversals.
Fiction is about reversals.
Yeah, like wrestling.
You know, in wrestling when you get a point...
for a reversal?
I'm talking about college wrestling.
Not the... Genuine wrestling.
Yeah, not these guys.
Not the... I know precisely what you're talking about.
Okay, not the steroid boys.
And what's the fifth one?
Oh, God, I can't believe it.
Yeah, there's another one, too.
Well, they're good rules.
I mean, I'm ready to appropriate them for my own years.
They really stood me in good stead.
So did you think your mother was prepping you for a career as a writer?
No, I don't.
I really don't.
She was just a good mom, you know, and was interested, and this was something she knew.
Did she do any fiction?
Did she do any fiction?
Well, only prose, no.
It was just for television.
Now, before she died, or before she got sick, actually,
She was attracting some interest from Hollywood and things were starting to happen.
And then she got breast cancer.
And quite young, she died when she was, I guess, she had just turned 50, just after her 50th birthday.
But she had the breast cancer.
Like when it came, it kind of, like five years before, or four maybe, it just put the brakes on all of that.
This was quite a while ago, thank you.
the whole career thing kind of stopped.
I mean, I don't understand it, you know.
And then she went through this whole horrible thing, and they go through, you know, where, yes, the two-year period's passed, and you're okay, and... Cancer is the worst thing.
Yeah.
And then, uh... Yeah, and then she wasn't okay.
And they found the recurrence when she went in to have plastic surgery to rebuild the breast after the mastectomy, and that's...
You know, the two-year period, you're okay.
Oh, can I go have this, rebuild that?
Yes.
It's like an elevator just that keeps going down.
So, in fact, she never, I never was a writer while she was alive.
She died in 1978, and I started writing my first book in 1979, and our first kid was born at the very end of 79, too.
See, she never saw the kids or knew that I was going to do that.
Oh, that's very bad.
Yeah, which was too bad.
Yes, I was.
From grade 1 through 12.
No, it doesn't compare, but I don't know whether it would if they were up there now either.
Yeah, they do.
They do.
You don't mind jumping around the board?
No, they do.
And there are some very good teachers.
But things have changed a lot.

Philosophically in the school system, you know, since when I was a kid, I mean, the trend was to kind of find bright kids and stream them out, you know, give them all they can handle, put them with other kids.
just like them, and enrich, and speed them a lot.
I don't know if the speeding up is so good, but the enrichment part is really good.
And now they're into more of an inclusion.
They certainly are in this school system, and bringing up the other kids and having everybody together, and so that... You're being very kind with your euphemisms.
Because people read papers here.
What's happening?
Oh, I think it'sthey're dreaming.
So you weremy math is if you graduated in 68, that would make you about Oh, I was born in 1947.
I'm 47 years old.
47 years old.
So your first book was published when you weren't even 30 yet.
Oh yeah, I was.
It was 1980, so take 15 away from 47 and 32.
Well, no, I didn't start young.
My whole 20s, I didn't do anything like this.
I worked for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, too, for five years.
So you kind of follow your mother professionally?
Well, no, she was in the drama department.
I worked in the current affairs department.
Were you writing or an administrative type of stuff?
Neither.
I was a producer.
Well, I started as just like a story editor.
I worked for a program that's a lot like All Things Considered.
It's called As It Happens.
In fact, Susan Stamford, who used to do All Things Considered.
Well, I know her.
I mean, we met way, way back then because she would come up and watch how we did it.
It was a really good program.
It was so exciting.
I loved it.
We had a lot of BBC people came over.
Oh, they were so... Those BBC people.
They were just wonderful.
I learned so much from them about doing this show.
And it was really exciting.
You'd come in every day.
with an hour and a half of time to fill, and nothing, no programming material, unless there was a tape or two left over.
Our job was to come up with two ideas.
How often?
Every day.
And then, every day, come up with the two ideas, find the interviewee, write up some questions for the interviewer, do a pre-interview, write up some questions for the interviewer,
go down in the studio during the afternoon, tape the interview, cut it, write a little intro, an extra... Yeah, and get it in by 5.30.
It'd be kind of nice if you were the on-air person, though.
The on-air person basically is using your stuff, though, right?
Well, no, they did the interviews on live in the afternoon.
Yeah.
Oh, no, we didn't do the... We prepared the interview and did a pre-interview to make sure the person could string two words together.
Because in radio, no matter how...
So it's live, these were live?
No, we very rarely went live.
I mean, the program was packaged live, but it was done in the afternoon.
So there was an opportunity for editing?
Yeah, we cut the tapes, and we cut them physically.
Oh, I see, okay.
Okay, up on a little Ampex machine, physically, with razor blades.
And I'm very, very clumsy with my small motor.
I mean, I often had blood, and often I would mangle tapes
And so you'd be up there on this deadline with twisted tape.
How long did you do this?
Well, I did that for a year, and I just loved it.
And then they started this TV program and asked me if I wanted to go to it.
And I thought, oh, TV is a step up.
You know, that would be a wise career.
And, of course, I loathed working in television.
Radio was so much more fun.
And I began kind of...
searching around for something else to do.
And I had a lot of... I got the idea for the first book.
It was a very successful book.
It did all right.
And I had a lot of vacation time coming in.
I thought I'm going to take it in one... I think it was three months.
And I thought I'd take it in one block and they let me do that.
And just see how this goes.
And at the end of three months, the book was just about finished.
How many people say it?
Well, it happened.
Did you do this with the contract?
No, it was totally speculative.
Did you have an agent?
No, I got him after.
What was the agent?
Well, I have a new agent.
In terms of managing my career, I've been an imbecile.
But I have a wonderful agent now, whose name is Molly Friedrich.
F-R-I-E-D-R-I-C-H?
F-R-I-E-D-R-I-C-H.
Yeah, her father is Otto Friedrich, who was a member of the editor of Time.
Oh, sure.
Oh, he's written a couple of pretty good books.
Yes, he sure has.
There's one on Paris in that.
There's one on the end of the world and people's conceptions of these world endings.
Yeah, and they have pretty good books.
In fact, New York Magazine a few, maybe, what was it, a month or two ago, did a cover on the hundred smartest New Yorkers.
You know their kind of stuff.
Was he there?
No, Molly was.
Molly was?
Yeah, Molly was.
That's terrific.
Ever since I landed with her, which was for this book.
Is this your first with Warner?
Yeah, Lights Out and Revolution No.
were with Mysterious, which is owned by Warren.
That's right.
Yeah, now... Okay, yeah, okay.
Oh, that's great.
Where was he?
In Boston?
Yeah.
You talk about not outlining, just parenthetically, he said this book.
He had a 254 page outline.
Wow.
No, I couldn't.
My outlines are...
Maybe 12 pages or something.
I like these organic things.
They just kind of grow.
But it is very carefully plotted, I have to say.
Your book is very carefully plotted.
See, I have to know that I'm going to hit these wave stations.
If I just know in my own mind that, okay, there's going to be this scene here, and I can get to it, and then Z is going to be something like this, I'm okay.
I have all these warning bells that go off in my mind if something's wrong.
For me, it's not a situation of like, I'm blocked, I can't think of how to do it.
I always can think of several ways, and the question is, what is the best way?
So I have to kind of, in my mind, it's like dominoes, think them all the way through.
If I go this way, I love this now, on page 80, what's it going to be like on page 250 if I do this?
That's the
It's almost like a computer, the plotting part.
You have to just... permutations.
Now, I've got a theory.
These are not the Boston Red Sox.
These are the Sox.
Yes.
However, it's Boston.
That's clear.
The terrain is very... And you really don't libel the ball team, so I'm... My guess is that maybe the mascot has something to do with it.
Yes, the Red Sox don't have a mascot, of course.
And they were adamantly opposed to doing that kind of a thing.
And I have to tell you, because I'm trying to do a lot of reading, that was a giveaway for me earlier.
I felt, not a giveaway, I felt this mascot, not here gratuitously, this mascot is here for a reason.
That's good.
That's my sense.
A good writer doesn't just throw something in here for the sake of having it there.
And the Red Sox have never had a mascot.
That was a technical reason why I didn't do Red Sox, but I had other reasons too.
that are really much harder to put into words.
But sometimes if I... I didn't want to use a real team because I didn't want to be trapped in their real history.
Yeah, but you are.
This is their first team.
You can win the world championship in fourth straight.
Yes, but I... Finally, hallelujah.
It's true, but I wanted to be free.
Okay, this is what.
I wanted the freedom to...
Are you going to have coffee?
I wouldn't mind a cup.
It would be great.
What do you like in it?
Just black for me.
Nothing.
You sure?
No milk.
Just milk.
And just black for me.
I didn't want to get... I want to be able to make my... The red light's on.
Okay.
Just do a visual check.
Everything's fine.
All right.
Is it turning?
Yeah, it's turning.
I don't want to get... I want to have the freedom to... It was a question of freedom.
to move away from... I didn't want to have to describe any city exactly.
Oh, there's no question that it's Boston.
But there's no question that it's Boston.
I know.
Okay, you and I know that, but there have been other pre-publications.
Well, you know what?
The Library Journal suggests the Chicago website.
Exactly.
That's what I was going to bring up.
I couldn't believe it.
I was just reading this on the way down.
I said, who?
Unbelievable.
I know.
Exactly.
So, there you go.
Yeah.
That's a good point.
Okay, and in fact, even my editor...
when I gave him the first hundred pages, said, oh, is this Boston or Chicago?
He doesn't know baseball.
See, a lot of people don't.
Like this guy from the Globe, you know, who confesses that he doesn't like baseball, or doesn't know much, or doesn't even like it.
But that was the good thing, because I was trying to, this book isn't just for baseball people.
No, of course not.
And that's why that Globe review I like, because he said he doesn't like baseball, but he likes the book.
Well, I think the triumph of the book is really that, as I was telling Connie on the way down, the way you really track this guy's descent into madness is very cleverly done.
He's kind of a jerk at the beginning, but he's not sociopathic at the point.
Well, that's the pushing it as far as you can.
I mean, it's taking the fandom and just going with it.
I mean, are there any, I mean, the stabbing of Monica Sellis, for instance?
That happened after I had, the stabbing of Monica Sellis happened after.
After you started the book?
Yes, after I had the whole, not after I started writing, but it happened after I had that all planned out.
Especially the kind of thing that,
Yes, exactly.

But that didn't... In fact, I didn't like it when it happened, the Monica Seles thing, because I thought, oh my God, they're going to say... He ripped off the Monica... Gill as a knife salesman was the very first thing in terms of Gill.
And I knew it had to end.
And also being a knife thrower and all this, I knew there was going to be a scene where he... He's terrific with the knife.
Yeah, where he...
So that was all set.
And then when this jerk jumps out of the tennis, you know, stands and... This guy screwed up my book.
Yeah, that's right.
I hated him.
You saw that potential back at the beginning of your brother, that ugly thing.
That chain, yeah.
Yeah, that's... Bringing it, stretching it to the... Yes, exactly.
...where you saw.
Yeah.
But it's rampant.
It's not unique.
I mean, the last time we went to an NFL game was years ago, and there was this one guy there cheering for Buffalo.
In fact, we saw O'Shea Simpson playing this game.
I said, oh yeah, I've never gone back to a game since.
It was very, very uncomfortable.
Was this at Foxborough?
Yeah, same thing.
I was going to tear this guy apart for cheering for my fault.
The guy says, hey, that's cool.
I won't see how it will work.
I know.
Well, that's what I'm talking about, like this deep emotional investment.
As though this really is a war, and these people are really carrying your pennant into battle.
Yeah.
And of course we see the soccer riots in Europe.
Yeah.
Crazy.
Yeah.
But, you know, one of the things this strike proves is that this is not a war.
This is not our army with their uniforms, you know.
Well, I think the fans are, for the most part, pretty resilient.
I think baseball's going to find that we can probably live without the major league.
Ah, jeez.
I just don't know.
I mean, have you seen some of those photographs that have been published?
There have been several.
I mean, there's always the same photograph.
It's a coach.
